qas.question: When was CBC's anologue upgrade extension set to expire?
At the deadline, which area lost broadcast entirely?
Did Barrie, Ontario lose signal for CBC, Radio-Canada, or both?
How many of the transmitters were purchased by the CRTC in order to be converted to digial?
What did the complete loss of service prompt the CRTC to grant?
What city in Canada started a new network after losing all coverage from the CBC and Radio-Canada?

plausible_answers.text: many markets subject to the transition deadline from losing signals for CBC or Radio-Canada

qas.question: The CRTC realized that it needed to break up the CBC's monopoly after it extended the deadline in order to prevent what?

context: Because rebroadcast transmitters were not planned to be converted to digital, many markets stood to lose over-the-air coverage from CBC or Radio-Canada, or both. As a result, only <b3_0>seven<b3_0/> of the markets subject to the August 31, 2011 transition deadline were planned to have both CBC and Radio-Canada in digital, and 13 other markets were planned to have either CBC or Radio-Canada in digital. In mid-August 2011, the CRTC granted the CBC <b4_0>an extension<b4_0/>, until <a0_0>August 31, 2012<a0_0/>, to continue operating its analogue transmitters in markets subject to the August 31, 2011 transition deadline. This CRTC decision prevented <b6_0>many markets subject to the transition deadline from losing signals for CBC or Radio-Canada<b6_0/>, or both at the transition deadline. At the transition deadline, <a1_0><b5_0>Barrie, Ontario<b5_0/><a1_0/> lost <a2_0>both<a2_0/> CBC and Radio-Canada signals as the CBC did not request that the CRTC allow these transmitters to continue operating.
